conclusion: Initial analysis of the problem involves understanding how shadows A, B, C, and D change in location and size when the light source moves backward.
Shadow A appears elongated and angled towards the bottom right corner of the image, originating from the birdcage object.
Shadow B is directly beneath the birdcage and is much smaller compared to A, suggesting the presence of another object near or within the birdcage.
Shadow C is small and located near the black cup-like object, falling to its left side.
Shadow D corresponds to the dagger, appearing as an elongated shape extending from the hilt toward the blade.
When the light source moves backward, shadows will lengthen due to the angle between the light source and the objects becoming more acute, and their direction may shift slightly.
Shadow A will extend further away from the birdcage, possibly moving more towards the bottom right, and become longer and thinner.
Shadow B will move slightly further away from the birdcage, aligning with the overall elongation of shadow A, and elongate but remain relatively close to the birdcage.
Shadow C will shift slightly to the left and extend further from the cup, growing longer as the light source moves back.
Shadow D will extend further away from the dagger, likely moving more towards the bottom left corner, and elongate while maintaining its general shape.

Final answer: Shadow A will move further to the bottom right and become longer; Shadow B will move slightly further away from the birdcage and elongate; Shadow C will shift slightly to the left and become longer; Shadow D will extend further towards the bottom left and elongate.
